contextual_info.app_usage_reason: Lina is a first-year college student who recently came out as bisexual in private circles. She uses the music app to discover identity-affirming music and observe what peers are listening to, hoping to feel more socially integrated.
contextual_info.privacy_expectations_and_vulnerabilities: Lina believes toggling visibility settings means she’s in full control. She underestimates passive visibility—assuming no one will see her activity unless she explicitly shares it.
contextual_info.information_to_control: Her listening patterns—especially tracks with LGBTQ+ themes or breakup songs—because they might implicitly signal her identity or emotional state.

privacy_tensions_and_costs.specific_privacy_response: Controlling Disclosure—she curates playlists manually but does not fully understand real-time visibility settings.
privacy_tensions_and_costs.costs: Despite her effort to selectively present herself, the app’s unclear sharing defaults expose her to judgment from conservative classmates who recently added her on social media.

privacy_invasive user journey.background: It's midterm season, and Lina is feeling overwhelmed and disconnected. After seeing a tweet about queer-friendly playlists, she opens the music app on her dorm laptop. She decides to activate the 'Friend Activity' sidebar to feel more connected to others and see what her new dormmates are listening to.
privacy_invasive user journey.unexpected_outcomes: After turning on 'Share my listening activity' to try out the Friend Activity sidebar, Lina’s current listening (including a breakup-themed LGBTQ+ song) becomes publicly visible. An acquaintance from her conservative hometown, who had recently synced their Facebook account and followed her, screenshots and shares it in a private Discord group mocking her identity. Lina didn’t realize that sharing her activity would retroactively make real-time plays visible to mutuals, especially if they had already followed her via other linked accounts.

scenes.scene_description: Lina wants to activate the 'Friend Activity' sidebar to feel less alone and see what her new peers are listening to. She expects this action to only make others' activities visible to her—not to broadcast her own music habits.

scene_user_flow.start: Lina launches the music app on her laptop in her dorm room.

scene_user_flow.action: She clicks on her profile picture on the top right corner of the screen.
scene_user_flow.interface: A drop-down menu appears under the user profile picture in the top-right corner of the screen.

Settings page with multiple subtitle sections including Account, Language, Explicit content, Autoplay, Audio quality, Your Library, Display, Zoom level, Social, Playback, Startup and window behavior, Storage, and Proxy Settings.

scene_user_flow.action: She scrolls down and finds the 'Display' section.
scene_user_flow.interface: The setting page under the 'Display' section, there are three toggle buttons: (1) 'Show the now-playing panel on click of play' (default ON), (2) 'Display short, looping visuals on tracks (Canvas)' (default ON), (3) 'See what your friends are playing' (default OFF).

scene_user_flow.action: She finds the 'See what your friends are playing' toggle button and switches it on.
scene_user_flow.system_action: The system checks and finds that she doesn't have any mutual-followed friend or synced Facebook friend who have turned on their 'Share my listening activity' setting to her.
scene_user_flow.interface: Friend Activity sidebar appears on the right third of the screen. The sidebar displays two messages: 'Let friends and followers see what you are listening to.' and 'Go to Settings > Social and enable “Share my listening activity”. You can turn this off at any time.' Below the messages, there is a large white button labeled 'Settings'.

scene_user_flow.action: She scrolls down and finds the 'Social' section.
scene_user_flow.interface: In the 'Social' section, there is one connection button and five toggle buttons. The connection button shows 'Connect with Facebook' with the description connect with Facebook to see what your friends are playing. The five toggle buttons are: (1) 'Publish my new playlists on my profile' (default ON), (2) 'Start a private session' (default OFF), (3) 'Share my listening activity' (default OFF), (4) 'Show my recently played artists on my public profile' (default ON), and (5) 'Show my followers and following lists on my public profile' (default ON).

scene_user_flow.action: She finds 'Share my listening activity' and switches the toggle button to ON.
scene_user_flow.system_action: The system checks and finds that she doesn't have any mutual-followed friend or synced Facebook friend who have turned on their 'Share my listening activity' setting to her.
scene_user_flow.interface: Friend Activity sidebar with the same two messages: 'Let friends and followers see what you are listening to.' and 'Go to Settings > Social and enable “Share my listening activity”. You can turn this off at any time.' Below the messages, there is a large white button labeled 'Settings'.

scene_user_flow.false_reasoning: Lina expected to *only* see what others are listening to, not realizing that enabling 'Share my listening activity' also publicly broadcasts her music in real-time to all mutual followers.
scene_user_flow.next_step: She considers turning on 'Private Session' next time but feels vulnerable now that her emotional state and identity cues were shared beyond her control.
